explain what I mean by that in traditional IOT installations our models tended our models or architectures
tended to be very hub-and-spoke right we would build solutions whether they're Wi-Fi or cellular where every node and
assume these little antenna things are nodes every note on the IOT network has to connect to the central node to the
Wi-Fi router to the cellular access point and if a node is too far away from that router tough luck it can't be part
of the network that's just the way that it goes that's how these systems are designed in addition if a Wi-Fi device
in this sort of a network and this sort of an installation goes off a line then
the I the network loses its IP address every device on the network loses its IP address and its ability to communicate
with with other devices on the network so there is no I there's no concept of a local network in a traditional
installation without the Gateway without the actual network device being online
so mesh networking which I'll admit is not a new concept but is relatively is maturing in many ways is evolving to
solve this problem because it operates on the principle that not every IOT device needs to actually be connected to
the Internet right and even those devices that are connected can be connected to one another so the devices
can actually through other peer devices find a pathway to the internet or that
messages from the cloud can actually find a pathway back to those in node devices this makes solutions more
resilient it makes them cheaper and fundamentally more secure and in this sort of an in this sort of scenario when
a device goes offline or loses its connection the network has its ability has an ability to auto route to actually
intelligently heal itself and find a different pathway to the Internet now
I mentioned that these there that there this has been around for a little while so if you've seen some of this in the
context of the smart home you may have heard of ZigBee or a z-wave you may have heard of Laura lein in the context of
larger area networks and the ability to connect low data rate networks it's at larger scales of miles or kilometers and
there's also thread now a thread is an interesting one because it was created by the team the nest team at Google so
it's purpose-built for IOT class devices that run in low power operating modes this is interesting to many companies
particle the company I work for is one of them because it's a low power it's a low power mesh networking protocol every
device in the network is ipv6 based there's no single point of failure it's tailored for these sorts of low-power
devices inexpensive radios that can actually do very interesting things and so as you're
looking into IOT devices out there as you're investigating the space keep an eye out for devices that actually do
have mesh networking capabilities built-in whether you're using these in the short term or not a few examples are
